headline: Elections Bipartisan Group Election Officials Raise Concerns Over Postal Service S
summary: A group of election officials voiced concerns on Wednesday over the United States Postal Service’s (USPS) capability of delivering mail-in ballots in an efficient and timely manner.The Details:The nonpartisanNational Association of Secretaries of State(NASS), which is made upalmost equallyof Democrats and Republicans, sent the head of the USPSa six-page lettersaying they feared “lost or delayed election mail” has led to the disenfranchisement of some American voters.For Context:The NASS emphasizes nonpartisanship as a core tenet, alternating its leadership between Democrats and Republicans.Key Quotes:The letter says, “We implore you to take immediate and tangible corrective action to address the ongoing performance issues,” and that “failure to do so will risk limiting voter participation and trust in the election process.” The USPS said it is “committed to the timely and secure delivery of the nation’s Election Mail” and local and state election officials “have brought any issues to our attention, we have promptly addressed those concerns, and we will continue to do so.”How The Media Covered It:Reuters (Center bias)included quotes from the USPS which reportedly said it delivered 99.89% of ballots within seven days in 2020.The New York Times (Lean Left bias)included that in 2020, USPS head Louis DeJoy’s proposed changes to the agency “led to an outcry from Democrats” and that he is a longtime Republican donor.
